title: Credit risk manager’s beautiful gamble on fashion
text:
Each piece is manufactured in Australia, a policy on which she won’t compromise. “This is where my finance brain comes in,” she says. “I’ve worked out a way to make that sustainable. And that is what true luxury is – things made well, built to last.”

The 'Oleander' silk duster jacket, $1400, complemented by luscious Tuscan light.

Manners designs two collections a year for a small coterie of private clients, in addition to her day job. She sells only through pop-up salons and her own online store, saying she is hesitant to sell in retail spaces she can’t control. For her, it’s more than just selling clothes.

“My clients work hard, they need a space where they can relax and enjoy the experience. I want to be able to provide that for them.” To that end, she’s hosting a three month pop-up in Sydney’s Double Bay, named Le Marche du Luxe, from October to December.

Last year, Manners hosted a pop-up of an altogether different kind, bringing together some of the women who inspire her most, from floral artist Dr Lisa Cooper to sound artist Claudio, and sending them to Florence, Italy, for a two-week installation showcasing fine art, photography and, of course, fashion. It was a hugely expensive undertaking, Manners says, revealing the final cost under her breath and adding, “It’s still hurting”.

Manners collaborated with Kailis to produce this limited-edition ring. POA. Kailis

But the gamble paid off, she says, as she made valuable connections with the Italian fashion industry, which will allow her to grow and evolve globally. And – bonus – one Florentine local told Manners that her designs reminded her of “early Pucci”.

“I mean, I can die happy now,” she jokes. “I wanted to do something that was about beauty for beauty’s sake. Because that’s how I lift myself out of the fog, that’s my self-care – surrounding myself with art, culture, photography. And I think we need that now, more than ever.”

Staging the two-week installation and a lavish gala dinner in Florence has paid dividends for Manners.

As part of the installation, she collaborated on fine jewellery with the West Australian brand Kailis. “I’ve been a Kailis customer for a long time, I love their products,” says Manners. “And as I was thinking about the installation and all the elements I needed, I thought, ‘I need a ring’. I had the exact design and colours in mind, I knew exactly what it looked like.” The company obliged, and the limited edition ring (POA) is available on Manners’ website.

Advertisement

As for quitting her day job, Manners isn’t in a hurry. “I’m on a mission to show people that you can do both: art and corporate work,” she says. She recalls telling a former boss about her desire to work in fashion. “He said, ‘Go for it – just don’t tell anyone.’ I thought, ‘Stuff that’.”

She points to the growing use of artificial intelligence in many industries. “The truth is, AI is coming in doing a whole bunch of work for us. So what separates us from AI? Creativity, connections, problem-solving. Why should I have to choose between my left and right brain?”

Wool-blend Tailor jacket, $795 and You Can box-pleat skirt, $850, photographed in Tuscany.

When she hires for her own team, Manners looks for people who have hobbies and passions outside the office. “Why wouldn’t I want to galvanise that? It shows you can manage your time, that you’re innovative, that you have a deeper and broader understanding of the world. That’s very powerful.”

While she admits that there is “probably an expiry date at some point” on pursuing fashion and finance, “I want to show people you don’t have to choose. You can be a serious business person and be serious about art. We love putting people into boxes but I am over that. If you have a point of view and you want to express it, it shouldn’t matter what else you do.”

NEED TO KNOW

Le Marche du Luxe pop-up runs from October 3 to December 24 at 2/5 Knox Street, Double Bay, Sydney.
description: Aneka Manners has no intention of letting her creative side take a back seat to her day job.
